title: Extinction Rebellion protests cost the same as 1,000 new police recruits
text:
Extinction Rebellion protests are said to have cost the Met £21 million (Kirsty O’Connor/PA)

Extinction Rebellion’s ‘autumn uprising’ cost police in London as much money as hiring 1,000 new officers, the Met’s police commissioner said today.

Cressida Dick revealed that policing protests across the city cost an estimated £21 million.

The starting salary for a police constable in the Met is £19,971 with an additional £2,373 London weighting.

Added to the £16 million that the group’s April protests cost the Met, the total bill for the taxpayer comes to £37 million.

Responding to the news, Extinction Rebellion London tweeted: ‘The IMF warns of potentially infinite costs if the climate emergency is not addressed urgently.

‘Companies are beginning to think about the enormous costs too.’

Officers were drafted in from across the city to help deal with the XR disruption (Picture: PA)

Officers arrest a man dressed as broccoli during an XR protest in Oxford Street (Picture: PA)

The two-week campaign by XR brought parts of central London to a standstill and led to more than 1,800 arrests.

Among the protesters’ targets were the financial district, London City Airport and even the transport network.

In response the Met Police issued a blanket ban on all Extinction Rebellion protests in the city, which XR sought to challenge at the High Court.

After a review, the Met determined the conditions banning the protesters from assembly are no longer necessary and lifted them as of Friday.

Climate activists said their ‘uprising’ – which was echoed by groups around the world – was aimed at ringing the alarm on the urgency of the climate crisis.

The group’s demands include net zero emissions by 2025 and for the government to establish a citizen’s assembly to tackle climate breakdown.
